tit.e: Animism
Animism
Animism

sen.j: アニミズム（英語animism）は生物・無機物を問わないすべてのものの中に霊魂、もしくは精霊が宿っているという考え方。
sen.e: Animism is a concept that every thing regardless of a living thing or a non-living object has a spirit or a soul.
Animism is a concept that every thing regardless of a living thing or a non-living object has a spirit or a soul.
Animism is a concept that every thing regardless of a living thing or a non-living object has a spirit or a soul.

sen.j: 19世紀後半、イギリスの人類学者、エドワード・バーネット・タイラーが著書『原始文化』（1871年）の中で使用し定着させた。
sen.e: In the late 19th century, Sir Edward Burnett TYLOR, an English anthropologist, used the term in his writing "Primitive Culture" (1871) and radicated it.
In the late 19th century, Sir Edward Burnett TYLOR, an English anthropologist, used the term in his writing "Primitive Culture" (1871) and established it.
In the late 19th century, Sir Edward Burnett TYLOR, an English anthropologist, used the term in his writing "Primitive Culture" (1871) and established it.

sen.j: 日本語では「汎霊説」、「精霊信仰」などと訳されている。
sen.e: In Japanese, animism is translated as "汎霊説(Hanreisetsu)" or "精霊信仰(Seirei Shinko)".
sen.cmt: 「汎霊説」の読みは確認できていません。
sen.e: In Japanese, animism is translated as 'Hanrei-setsu' (all objects have spirits or souls) or 'Seirei Shinko' (worship of nature).
sen.cmt: 汎霊説（全てのものに霊性を認める思想）→'Hanrei-setsu' (all objects have spirits or souls)としました。精霊信仰→'Seirei Shinko' (worship of nature)としました。
sen.e: In Japanese, animism is translated as 'Hanrei-setsu' (all objects have spirits or souls) or 'Seirei Shinko' (worship of nature).

sen.j: この語はラテン語のアニマ（anima）に由来し、気息・霊魂・生命といった意味である。
sen.e: The term derives from a Latin word "anima," which means breath, spirit, and life.
The term derives from a Latin word "anima," which means breath, spirit, and life.
The term derives from a Latin word "anima," which means breath, spirit, and life.

tit.e: Summary
Summary
Summary

tit.j: タイラーとマレットのそれぞれのアニミズム観
tit.e: Views of the animism by Tylor and Marett
Views of the animism by Tylor and Marett
Views of the animism by Tylor and Marett

sen.j: タイラーはアニミズムを「霊的存在への信仰」とし、宗教的なるものの最小限の定義とした。
sen.e: Tylor defined the animism as "a faith in spiritual beings," which is the minimal definition of a religious thing.
Tylor defined the animism as 'a faith in spiritual beings,' which is the minimal definition of a religious thing.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。
sen.e: Tylor defined the animism as 'a faith in spiritual beings,' which is the minimal definition of a religious thing.

sen.j: 彼によれば諸民族の神観念は人格を投影したものという（擬人化、擬人観、エウヘメリズム）。
sen.e: He wrote that the notion of god in many tribes reflect a personality (personification, sense of personification, euhemerism).
He wrote that the notion of god in many tribes reflect a personality (personification, sense of personification, euhemerism).
He wrote that the notion of god in many tribes reflect a personality (personification, sense of personification, euhemerism).

sen.j: 現在でもこの語は宗教学で触れる際など抜きにしては考えられない語であるが、一方タイラーのアニミズム観に対してはマレット（Robert Ranulph Marett）が「未開」民族の間では人格性を欠いた力あるいは生命のような観念もあるとした。
sen.e: Even in the present day, it is inevitable to use the term when discussing the philosophy of religion, and, contrary to Tylor's view of the animism, Robert Ranulph MARETT advocated that there is a notion of a power or a life without a personality among "barbarian" tribes.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Even in the present day, it is inevitable to use the term when discussing the philosophy of religion, and, contrary to Tylor's view of the animism, Robert Ranulph MARETT advocated that there is a notion of a power or a life without a personality among 'barbarian' tribes.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。
sen.e: Even in the present day, it is inevitable to use the term when discussing the philosophy of religion, and, contrary to Tylor's view of the animism, Robert Ranulph MARETT advocated that there is a notion of a power or a life without a personality among 'barbarian' tribes.

sen.j: そのアニミズム以前の状態をプレアニミズム (pre-animism) と呼び、同様の概念はアニマティズム（animatism）、ヴァイタリズム（vitalism）、ダイナミズム（dynamism）などとも称された。
sen.e: The state before the animism was called "pre-animism," and a similar concept was also referred to as "animatism," "vitalism," "dynamism," and so on.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The state before the animism was called "pre-animism," and a similar concept was also referred to as "animatism," "vitalism," "dynamism," and so on.
The state before the animism was called "pre-animism," and a similar concept was also referred to as "animatism," "vitalism," "dynamism," and so on.

sen.j: また研究姿勢に対しては類推的とか、進化主義的であるとかの批判もされる。
sen.e: The approach to the study is sometimes criticized to be analogical or evolutional.
The approach to the study is sometimes criticized to be analogical or evolutional.
The approach to the study is sometimes criticized to be analogical or evolutional.

tit.j: 世界中で普遍的な「始まりのとしての原始宗教であるアニミズム」とその蔑視
tit.e: Globally universal "animism which is a primitive religion as a start" and discrimination of it
Globally universal 'animism which is a primitive religion as a start' and discrimination of it
tit.cmt: 原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。
tit.e: Globally universal 'animism which is a primitive religion as a start' and discrimination of it

sen.j: 霊的存在が肉体や物体を支配するという精神観、霊魂観（日本で言えば「依り代」に近い観念）は、世界的にひろく宗教、習俗の中で一般に存在している。
sen.e: The spiritual view that a spiritual being governs a body or an object (a concept close to yorishiro (object representative of a divine spirit) in Japan) is commonly present in religions and folkways over the world.

The spiritual view that a spiritual being governs a body or an object (a concept close to yorishiro [object representative of a divine spirit] in Japan) is commonly present in religions and folkways over the world.
sen.cmt: 括弧内括弧を［］に訂正しました。
sen.e: The spiritual view that a spiritual being governs a body or an object (a concept close to yorishiro [object representative of a divine spirit] in Japan) is commonly present in religions and folkways over the world.

sen.j: キリスト教が先進のものというヨーロッパの視点から、アニミズムはかつて原始的な未開社会のものであると考えられた。
sen.e: From the European view point that Christianity was advanced, the animism used to belong to a primitive and barbarian society.
From the European view point that Christianity was advanced, the animism used to belong to a primitive and barbarian society.
From the European view point that Christianity was advanced, the animism used to belong to a primitive and barbarian society.

sen.j: リュシアン・レヴィ＝ブリュールの『未開社会の思惟』など、民族学や文化人類学の南太平洋（トロブリアンド諸島）やブラジルの先住民のその根本的な考察観にうかがい知ることができる。
sen.e: It can be seen in the fundamental view of the natives in the South Pacific (Trobriand Islands) and Brazil in the folklore and the cultural anthropology, as seen in "How Natives Think" by Lucien Lévy-Bruhl.

It can be seen in the fundamental view of the natives in the South Pacific (Trobriand Islands) and Brazil in the folklore and the cultural anthropology, as seen in "How Natives Think" by Lucien Lévy-Bruhl.

It can be seen in the fundamental view of the natives in the South Pacific (Trobriand Islands) and Brazil in the folklore and the cultural anthropology, as seen in "How Natives Think" by Lucien Lévy-Bruhl.

tit.e: Shinto and animism
Shinto and animism
Shinto and animism
Concept of Shinto
Concept of Shinto
Concept of Shinto

sen.j: 太古からある神道の始まりである古神道においては、必ずしも神奈備（かんなび・神々が鎮座する森や山）に代表される神籬（ひもろぎ・鎮守の森や御神木の巨木や森林信仰）や磐座（いわくら・夫婦岩などの巨石や山岳信仰）は依り代としての対象だけではなく、常世（とこよ・神の国や神域）と現世（うつしよ・俗世いわゆる現実世界）の端境（はざかい）や各々を隔てるための結界の意味もある。
sen.e: In Ancient Shinto since ancient days, which was the origin of Shinto, himorogi (worship of a sacred shrine forest, a giant sacred tree, or a forest) and iwakura (worship of a giant rock such as meotoiwa (wedded rocks) and mountains) represented by kannabi (a mountain or a forest where the divine soul resides) are not necessarily an object as the yorishiro, but also serve as borders between tokoyo (country of god or sacred area) and utsushiyo (mortal world or real world) and barriers to separate them.

In Ancient Shinto since ancient days, which was the origin of Shinto, himorogi (worship of a sacred shrine forest, a giant sacred tree, or a forest) and iwakura (worship of a giant rock such as meotoiwa [wedded rocks] and mountains) represented by kannabi (a mountain or a forest where the divine soul resides) are not necessarily an object as the yorishiro, but also serve as borders between tokoyo (country of god or sacred area) and utsushiyo (mortal world or real world) and barriers to separate them.
sen.cmt: 括弧内括弧を［］に訂正しました。
sen.e: In Ancient Shinto since ancient days, which was the origin of Shinto, himorogi (worship of a sacred shrine forest, a giant sacred tree, or a forest) and iwakura (worship of a giant rock such as meotoiwa [wedded rocks] and mountains) represented by kannabi (a mountain or a forest where the divine soul resides) are not necessarily an object as the yorishiro, but also serve as borders between tokoyo (country of god or sacred area) and utsushiyo (mortal world or real world) and barriers to separate them.

sen.j: あくまでも自然崇拝・精霊崇拝（アニミズム）を内包し、その延長線としての祖先崇拝も観念や、祈祷師・占いなどのシャーマニズムとも渾然一体となっている。
sen.e: The nature worship and the spirit worship (animism) are absolutely included, and a concept of the ancestor worship by extension and the shamanism including shamans and fortune-telling are also involved.

The nature worship and the spirit worship (animism) are absolutely included, and a concept of the ancestor worship by extension and the shamanism including shamans and fortune-telling are also involved.

The nature worship and the spirit worship (animism) are absolutely included, and a concept of the ancestor worship by extension and the shamanism including shamans and fortune-telling are also involved.

tit.e: Deities residing in shinrabansho (all things in nature, the whole creation)
Deities residing in shinrabansho (all things in nature, the whole creation)
Deities residing in shinrabansho (all things in nature, the whole creation)

sen.j: 古神道から流れの民間信仰や価値観として、上記の森羅万象とする範囲を超越した行為があり、敵や人の食べ物として命を落としたものでさえ祀った蒙古塚や鯨塚などが存在する。
sen.e: As a folk beliefs and sense of value deriving from Ancient Shinto, there are behaviors beyond the range of the above-mentioned shinrabansho, and there are even tumulus for Mongolian warriors and tumulus for whales worshiping those lost their lives as enemies or food.

As a folk beliefs and sense of value deriving from Ancient Shinto, there are behaviors beyond the range of the above-mentioned shinrabansho, and there are even tumulus for Mongolian warriors and tumulus for whales worshiping those lost their lives as enemies or food.

As a folk beliefs and sense of value deriving from Ancient Shinto, there are behaviors beyond the range of the above-mentioned shinrabansho, and there are even tumulus for Mongolian warriors and tumulus for whales worshiping those lost their lives as enemies or food.

sen.j: 上記のアニミズムの説明の中で無機質とあるが、あくまでも対象は自然の中の海・山河や岩・大地や風雨・雷といった気象現象などに留まる物であり、道具などの人工についての特筆はない。
sen.e: While the above explanation of the animism refers to "non-living," the object absolutely remains in the range of the seas, mountains, rivers, rocks, grounds, weathers such as winds, rains, and thunders, and the like in the nature, and there is no description of artificial objects such as tools.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: While the above explanation of the animism refers to "non-living," the object absolutely remains in the range of the seas, mountains, rivers, rocks, grounds, weathers such as winds, rains, and thunders, and the like in the nature, and there is no description of artificial objects such as tools.

While the above explanation of the animism refers to "non-living," the object absolutely remains in the range of the seas, mountains, rivers, rocks, grounds, weathers such as winds, rains, and thunders, and the like in the nature, and there is no description of artificial objects such as tools.

sen.j: その点においては、九十九神（つくもがみ）や道具塚や針供養などの人工物にまで広がりその種類は多岐にわたる。
sen.e: In this point, even the artificial objects are covered including Tsukumogami, tumulus for tools, and Hari-kuyo (Solemn rite of respect and thanksgiving for broken needles and pins), with extremely large variety.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In this point, even the artificial objects are covered including Tsukumogami, tumulus for tools, and Hari-kuyo (Solemn rite of respect and thanksgiving for broken needles and pins), with extremely large variety.

In this point, even the artificial objects are covered including Tsukumogami, tumulus for tools, and Hari-kuyo (Solemn rite of respect and thanksgiving for broken needles and pins), with extremely large variety.

sen.j: 人の営み「勤しみ（いそしみ）」にも神が宿ると考え農業・林業・漁業などにおいて、例えば稲作信仰の米作りは神事であり、これらの自然と密着した一次産業だけでなく、二次産業においても建築・土木・鉱業や鍛冶・たたら（日本の古式製鉄）の工業や醸造・酒造といった食品加工業にも神が宿ると考えた。
sen.e: In the faith that deities reside in a human activity, for example, rice production was a divine service in folk religion for rice cultivation in the agriculture and fishery, and, not only in the primary industry tightly connected to the nature but also in the secondary industry, it was believed that deities reside in construction, civil engineering, mining, industries of blacksmith and tatara (ancient iron-making in Japan), and food processing industry such as brewing.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the faith that deities reside in a human activity, for example, rice production was a divine service in folk religion for rice cultivation in the agriculture and fishery, and, not only in the primary industry tightly connected to the nature but also in the secondary industry, it was believed that deities reside in construction, civil engineering, mining, industries of blacksmith and tatara (ancient iron-making in Japan), and food processing industry such as brewing.

In the faith that deities reside in a human activity, for example, rice production was a divine service in folk religion for rice cultivation in the agriculture and fishery, and, not only in the primary industry tightly connected to the nature but also in the secondary industry, it was believed that deities reside in construction, civil engineering, mining, industries of blacksmith and tatara (ancient iron-making in Japan), and food processing industry such as brewing.

sen.j: 職業としての神事があり、神棚や装束を備え纏い、行程の節目に固有の儀式を行い、現在も引き継いでいる職業は多く存在する。
sen.e: There were divine services in each occupation, where a household Shinto altar was set, a costume was worn, and unique rites were performed at milestones in the process, and many occupations still continue the services in the present day.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There were divine services in each occupation, where a household Shinto altar was set, a costume was worn, and unique rites were performed at milestones in the process, and many occupations still continue the services in the present day.

There were divine services in each occupation, where a household Shinto altar was set, a costume was worn, and unique rites were performed at milestones in the process, and many occupations still continue the services in the present day.

sen.j: そして、霊や精霊だけでなくその表現や捉え方は命・魂・御霊（みたま）や神・尊（みこと）でもあり、その区別や概念も曖昧であり、それを分類や定義付けることなく享受してきた。
sen.e: Not only the soul and the spirit but also their expressions and understandings were the life, the soul, the departed soul, the god, and the deity, where the distinction among them or concepts of them were vague, which have not categorized or defined in the past.

Not only the soul and the spirit but also their expressions and understandings were the life, the soul, the departed soul, the god, and the deity, where the distinction among them or concepts of them were vague, which have not categorized or defined in the past.

Not only the soul and the spirit but also their expressions and understandings were the life, the soul, the departed soul, the god, and the deity, where the distinction among them or concepts of them were vague, which have not categorized or defined in the past.

sen.j: ただし、強弱や主客といえるような区別は存在し、大きいもの（巨石・山河）や古いもの長く生きたものが、その力が大きいと考えると同時に尊ばれた。
sen.e: However, there were some distinction such as strong and weak or main and sub, where larger ones (giant rock, mountain and river) and long-living old ones were regarded to have a stronger power and valued.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, there were some distinction such as strong and weak or main and sub, where larger ones (giant rock, mountain and river) and long-living old ones were regarded to have a stronger power and valued.

However, there were some distinction such as strong and weak or main and sub, where larger ones (giant rock, mountain and river) and long-living old ones were regarded to have a stronger power and valued.

sen.j: 日本神話にある、人格神などの人としての偶像を持つ神々も信仰の対象とし、「それらの神がその他の森羅万象の神々を統べる」という考え方に時代とともに移っていった。
sen.e: The deities having an idol as a human such as a humanized divinity in Japanese myths were also objects of worship, then the age changed to accept the concept that "these deities govern other deities of shinrabansho."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The deities having an idol as a human such as a humanized divinity in Japanese myths were also objects of worship, then the age changed to accept the concept that 'these deities govern other deities of shinrabansho.'
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。
sen.e: The deities having an idol as a human such as a humanized divinity in Japanese myths were also objects of worship, then the age changed to accept the concept that 'these deities govern other deities of shinrabansho.'

tit.j: 神社神道と古神道と他宗教との習合
tit.e: Syncretization of Shrine Shinto and the Ancient Shinto with other religions
Syncretization of Shrine Shinto and the Ancient Shinto with other religions
Syncretization of Shrine Shinto and the Ancient Shinto with other religions

sen.j: その後、古来からある神殿の形式や祭礼の様式・儀式に加え、奈良時代頃からは、仏教や仏教建築の形式や儀式の影響を受け、平安時代には、道教の陰陽五行思想を神道に取り入れ、陰陽師と陰陽思想が台頭し、そして現在の神社神道にもその陰陽五行思想が存在する。
sen.e: Later, in addition to the forms of the ancient temples and the styles and the rites of the ceremonies, with an influence of Buddhism, the form of the Buddhist architecture, and the rites since Nara period, Inyo [Onmyo] gogyo shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Xing Idea) was taken into Shinto in the Taoism in Heian period, Onmyoji (Master of Yin yang) and the cosmic dual forces ideology emerged, whereby the Inyo gogyo shiso is present in the present Shrine Shinto.

Later, in addition to the forms of the ancient temples and the styles and the rites of the ceremonies, with an influence of Buddhism, the form of the Buddhist architecture, and the rites since Nara period, Inyo (Onmyo) gogyo shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Xing Idea) was taken into Shinto in the Taoism in Heian period, Onmyoji (Master of Yin yang) and the cosmic dual forces ideology emerged, whereby the Inyo gogyo shiso is present in the present Shrine Shinto.

Later, in addition to the forms of the ancient temples and the styles and the rites of the ceremonies, with an influence of Buddhism, the form of the Buddhist architecture, and the rites since Nara period, Inyo (Onmyo) gogyo shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Xing Idea) was taken into Shinto in the Taoism in Heian period, Onmyoji (Master of Yin yang) and the cosmic dual forces ideology emerged, whereby the Inyo gogyo shiso is present in the present Shrine Shinto.

sen.j: その後には古神道と仏教や密教が習合した山岳信仰である修験道などが誕生し、江戸時代には儒教と習合した儒教神道も生まれた。
sen.e: Shugendo, which is a mountain worship combining the Ancient Shinto, Buddhism, and Esoteric Buddhism, and other religions emerged later, and Confucian Shinto combined with Confucianism emerged in Edo period.

Shugendo, which is a mountain worship combining the Ancient Shinto, Buddhism, and Esoteric Buddhism, and other religions emerged later, and Confucian Shinto combined with Confucianism emerged in Edo period.

Shugendo, which is a mountain worship combining the Ancient Shinto, Buddhism, and Esoteric Buddhism, and other religions emerged later, and Confucian Shinto combined with Confucianism emerged in Edo period.

sen.j: 近代から現在の神道においては、一般に八百万の神と称されるように、古神道も不可分であることから、様々な物体や事象にそれぞれ宿る神が、信仰されているためアニミズムと同一視される事もある。
sen.e: As generally referred to as eight million different deities, because deities residing in various objects and events have been worshiped in Shinto from modern times to the present indivisible from the Ancient Shinto, Shinto is sometimes regarded identical to the animism.

As generally referred to as eight million different deities, because deities residing in various objects and events have been worshiped in Shinto from modern times to the present indivisible from the Ancient Shinto, Shinto is sometimes regarded identical to the animism.

As generally referred to as eight million different deities, because deities residing in various objects and events have been worshiped in Shinto from modern times to the present indivisible from the Ancient Shinto, Shinto is sometimes regarded identical to the animism.

sen.j: ただし、現在の神社神道において依り代となるものは一定の範囲に限定されており、神籬や磐座は玉垣になり、鎮守の森は神体として扱われなくなった。
sen.e: However, since the yorishiro is limited within a certain range in the present Shrine Shinto, the himorogi and the iwakura became tamagaki (fence around a shrine), and now the sacred shrine forest is not treated as a shintai (sacred object) any more.

However, since the yorishiro is limited within a certain range in the present Shrine Shinto, the himorogi and the iwakura became tamagaki (fence around a shrine), and now the sacred shrine forest is not treated as a shintai (sacred object) any more.

However, since the yorishiro is limited within a certain range in the present Shrine Shinto, the himorogi and the iwakura became tamagaki (fence around a shrine), and now the sacred shrine forest is not treated as a shintai (sacred object) any more.

sen.j: このように神社神道では、万物に神が宿っているわけではないという点でアニミズムとは異なっているともいえる。
sen.e: As described above, Shrine Shinto may be different from the animism in that deities do not reside in everything.
As described above, Shrine Shinto may be different from the animism in that deities do not reside in everything.
